Review of RCOG Green-top Guideline No 72 Care of Women with Obesity in Pregnancy: Clarification to points 1.2, 2.0, 4.0, 7.1,7.3, 7.4, 7.5, 7.6, 8.1, 8.1.1, 8.3, 8.5, 8.6, 8.9, 8.10, 8.13, 8.16, 9.1, 11.2 and 12.3,

data.text: Contents
Advice on Healthy Eating and Physical Exercise .................................................... 5
Appendix C: Supplementary Schedule of Antenatal Visits for Women with raised BMI in addition to normal care pathway ........................................................................ 18
Introduction
To provide high quality care, planned in partnership with a patient who has a raised body mass index (BMI) of 30 and above at the first antenatal consultation.

More than a third (34%) of the women who died in 2015–17 were obese and a further 24% were overweight. Obesity has been shown to be associated with higher odds of maternal death in the UK with its effect primarily manifested through medical comorbidities (Nair, Kurinczuk et al. 2015, Nair, Knight et al. 2016).
In addition, there is considerable impact on service delivery such as associated cost of complications and provision of specialist equipment, such as beds, hoists and
chairs.
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a
service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to Appendix 1)
Aim
Identification of the patient at risk due to increased BMI.
Assessment of the risks by health care professionals.
Arrangement and documentation of plan of care.
Referring them to appropriate specialities.
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Definition
Body mass index equals weight in kilogrammes (kg) divided by height in metres.  (Refer to appendix A for classification details)
Risks
Infertility and miscarriage;
Birth defects in particular neural tube defects;
Urinary tract infections;
Gestational diabetes;
Hypertension, pre-eclampsia and eclampsia;
Failure to progress in labour;
Fetal macrosomia;
Thrombophlebitis;
Venous thromboembolism;
Pulmonary embolism;
Puerperal infections;
Stillbirths and early neonatal deaths;
Postpartum haemorrhage;
Caesarean section and peri-operative morbidity;
Anaesthetic risks including difficulty in tracheal intubation;
Hiatus hernia.
Advice on healthy eating and physical exercise

To maintain continuity of care, all midwives should discuss and offer support for women with raised BMI in pregnancy as detailed in this guideline. The woman should be advised that a healthy diet and being physically active will benefit

both herself and her unborn child during pregnancy and will also help her achieve a healthy weight after giving birth. Dieting to lose weight is not recommended during pregnancy as it may harm the health of the unborn child. Advise calorie intake needs only rise in the third trimester by 200 calories per day. Many obese women are nutrient deficient so a focus should be on improving the quality of diet where possible.
Advice on how to use Healthy Start Vouchers to increase the fruit and vegetable intake of those eligible for the healthy Start scheme (Women under  years and those who are receiving benefit payment)

Women should not be routinely reweighed during pregnancy. Only weigh again if nutrition is a concern or if the woman requests it. If weight is of concern, the gestational weight gain chart in the Antenatal Care record can be used, and deviations should generate a dietetic referral. However, all women with a BMI over 30 should be weighed at 36 weeks for manual handling assessment and postnatal Clexane calculation.

There is no current consensus on recommended weight gain in pregnancy, as the amount of weight a woman may gain in pregnancy can vary due to increased body fat, the unborn child, placenta, amniotic fluid and increased blood and fluid volume. Institute of Medicine Guidelines (USA) recommend women with a BMI of ≥  kg/m

should gain between 5-9kg throughout the pregnancy. This weight increase was linked to optimal pregnancy outcomes in observational studies. However, due to paucity of evidence the RCOG advises a focus on a healthy diet rather than prescribed weight gain targets.

The Patient Information Leaflet for women with a raised BMI should be given and discussed at booking. Many women and their partners have pre-existing social and cultural beliefs about pregnancy diet and weight gain. These views should be considered and women helped to identify where they can make changes appropriate to them. At each appointment it is important to encourage women to continue with the changes identified.

If women exercised regularly before pregnancy, they should be able to continue with no adverse effects. Advise that moderate intensity physical activity will not harm her or her unborn child and is beneficial, but the advice must be tailored to the women as women with a high BMI are more likely to experience arthritis and SPD (Symphysis Pubis Dysfunctions). Advice could include:
Recreational exercise such as swimming
Aim of recreational exercise to stay fit rather than reach peak fitness
If women have not exercised before begin with 5 minutes of continuous exercise three times per week increasing gradually to 30 minutes
She can also be referred to the G.P exercise referral scheme. Referral pads available in antenatal clinic/ WJC and St Peters Midwife-led Units
Antenatal assessment

All women with a BMI of ≥ 30kg/m should have multi-disciplinary care; however if there are no further risks identified during the pregnancy episode and BMI is below 35, the women should continue on a low risk care pathway.

8.1.1 Any woman that has had previous bariatric surgery should have consultant led care as they are considered high risk. They should have a referral to a dietician for advice regarding their nutritional needs and will need screening for iron, folate ferritin vitamin B12 and fat soluble vitamins.
All patients must have their BMI calculated at booking and recorded in their maternity record book in the designated box.

Pregnant patients with a BMI of ≥ 30kg/m2 should have a discussion regarding the most appropriate place of birth. Women with a BMI of ≥  kg/m2 should be booked for Obstetric Consultant-led care and deliver in the Consultant-led Unit at Broomfield Hospital
For women with a BMI of ≥ 30kg/m2, the booking midwife should complete
the ‘Pregnancy and labour care pathway for women with BMI ≥ 30kg/m2 along with the supplement schedule of care and gestational weight gain chart' and secure
this in the ‘Antenatal Care Record'
(Refer to Appendix C)
An appropriately trained professional should discuss risks associated with

pregnancy and delivery with the patient in the antenatal period. The following should be discussed and recorded on the proforma (Refer to Appendix B). Women can be encouraged to reduce these risks by adopting healthier behaviours as described in Section 6.0 and the Patient Information Leaflet.
The increased risk of miscarriage and still birth
Difficulties in assessing fetal growth,fetal position and in auscultation of the fetal heart.
Imaging difficulties at ultrasound scan
Increased risk of neural tubal defects (NTDs)
Importance of regular attendance for blood pressure (BP) and urinalysis recordings
Importance of having OGTT to determine gestational diabetes
Higher chance of having a macrosomic baby and the complications of this i.e. increased risk of shoulder dystocia
Discussing the risks associated with thrombosis and prophylactic measures
Increased risk of having lower segment caesarean section) LSCS
Increased risk of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH)
Increased risk of complications of wound healing.
The need for continual electronic fetal monitoring (EFM) in labour and difficulties in obtaining a good quality recording.
Difficulties associated with any anaesthetic interventions

A risk assessment for VTE should be undertaken at booking and anti-coagulants commenced for appropriate women (VTE Assessment page 10-11 of Antenatal Care record). All women should be made aware of symptoms of DVT and to access healthcare without delay if they develop symptoms.
All patients with BMI of ≥ 35kg/m2 should be advised to take an increased dose of folic acid of 5mg per day until  completed weeks of pregnancy.
All women, particularly those with BMI of ≥ 30kg/m2 should be advised to take 10 micrograms of vitamin D per day throughout her pregnancy and whilst breastfeeding.

Women with a BMI of 35kg/m or more at their first visit are at moderate risk of pre- eclampsia and should be given Aspirin 150mg orally per day (this should be prescribed by GP or obstetrician) from  weeks onwards until birth. (Refer to Antenatal management of pre-eclampsia and hypertensions; 11006 for complete list of patients in whom aspirin is indicated)
At booking all patients with BMI ≥ 30kg/m2, should be offered a random glucose and HbA1c blood test and at  weeks a fasting glucose and HbA1c test, unless indicated earlier.

An appropriate size blood pressure cuff to record blood pressure must be used in all settings. An over-estimation of blood pressure by approximately  mmHg occurs if normal sized cuffs are used in obese patients. To determine cuff size needed it is necessary to measure the circumference of the middle upper arm.
All patients with a BMI ≥ 30kg/m2 at booking and on any hospital admission should have:
A Waterlow score (tissue viability risk assessment) completed and documented in the health care records.

A risk assessment for thrombosis (VTE) and receive appropriate thromboprophylaxis post-delivery (Refer to the guideline for ‘Thromboprophylaxis and treatment during labour and delivery including caesarean section'; register number 08033 and the guideline for the ‘VTE risk assessment and thromboprophylaxis in maternity; register number 12007).

When a decision for induction of labour or caesarean section is made and on any hospital admission the patient should be weighed so that the weight bearing capacity of equipment can be assessed and be put in place for the patient's admission. (Refer to Appendix D)
Induction of labour should not be booked at the weekend for women with BMI ≥40kg/m. The Labour Ward Manager should be informed at the time of booking

induction or caesarean for women with BMI ≥50kg/m so that appropriate equipment can be obtained for the admission. Equipment can be obtained by contacting the lifting and handling team on extension 4781, 48 hours prior to elective admission.
In addition women with a BMI ≥ 40kg/m2 should be referred for an anaesthetic
consultant appointment at 32 weeks gestation; plus or minus 7 days; however this

should be assessed on an individual basis up until term. The anaesthetic consultant should discuss the management plan for labour and delivery for women with a BMI ≥ 40kg/m2 and this review should be documented in the health care records.
Women with a BMI of ≥  should have serial growth scans at 34 and 38 weeks gestation followed by a consultant appointment.
Induction of labour

If induction of labour is required, a consultant obstetrician should liaise with the multi-disciplinary team to ensure that the decision occurs during daytime hours- 08:00 – 16:00) when senior personnel are more readily available. Induction or planned caesarean section for women with BMI ≥ 40kg/m should be booked Monday to Friday between 08:00- 16:00 to ensure the maximum availability of senior staff.
Presentation must be confirmed on ultrasound scan prior to induction of labour.
Any plan of care must be discussed and agreed with the patient and clearly documented in her health care records.

The patient, when in labour, should be cared for in room 6 (bariatric room) to provide the extra space for the patient and necessary equipment, if it is available. If room 6 is in use and a second bariatric patient is admitted, a second hoist and appropriate size wheelchair can be obtained from the equipment library for use in an appropriately accessible room.
Fetal Monitoring can be challenging in women with a raised BMI so discussion with the Obstetric Consultant is required for early fetal scalp electrode if appropriate.
Intrapartum care

On admission the Labour Ward Co-ordinator, obstetric registrar/Consultant on call and anaesthetic registrar must be informed of all patients with a BMI 35kg/m2 or above in pregnancy. At this stage strong consideration should be given to early epidural analgesia; although it is important that patients are encouraged to mobilise during labour.
The patient should be encouraged to manage their diabetes until labour becomes established.
The consultant obstetrician and consultant anaesthetist must be informed if any problems are anticipated, such as difficulty gaining venous access or siting an epidural or if the BMI is ≥  kg/m2

Maintaining normality during labour minimises the risk of complications. However there is an increased risk of caesarean section with increased BMI and therefore women with a BMI of ≥ 35kg/m2 should not eat in labour, but have isotonic drinks during labour to prevent ketosis without a concomitant increase in gastric volume.
Furthermore, the patient with a ≥ BMI 35kg/m2 should receive antacid prophylaxis in labour.

There should be a low threshold for obstetric consultant involvement at all stages. The on call Consultant obstetrician should be kept informed of the progress, instrumental delivery should be undertaken by the obstetric consultant or under their supervision.
Intravenous access should be obtained and bloods taken for full blood count, group and save, and uric acid and electrolytes analysis.
Fetal monitoring in labour may be more difficult and consideration should be given to application of a fetal scalp electrode, if abdominal monitoring is unsatisfactory.
Caesarean section
Ensure the operating table will support the patient's weight. This should be highlighted at the antenatal Anaesthetic appointment. (Refer to Appendix D for safe working load for. equipment)
A consultant obstetrician/anaesthetist opinion is required for patients with a BMI ≥ 40 kg/m2. (Refer to Appendix B)
Skin  Prep is  essential,  as  the  women  have  increased  risk  of  wound infection. Special attention should be given to clean under the panniculus and in the groin area.
Adequate length of incision is vital as poor access can be physically taxing and will increase the operative time so adding to the risk.
Deeper retractors may be needed to facilitate surgery.
For the skin closure, particularly in morbidly obese patients, an interrupted suture may be better so that if a small haematoma develops, a few sutures can be removed to help its resolution.
PICO dressings should be considered in all high BMI cases having caesarean sections.
Postnatal care
Encourage early ambulation.

Correct size thromboembolic deterrent (TED) stockings should be offered and worn for the duration of the patient's stay irrespective of mode of delivery .Offer for 5 days postnatally or until fully ambulatory.

Postnatal risk assessment for DVT should be undertaken and thromboprophylaxis prescribed for  days. The dose should be tailored in conjunction with the patient's weight.(Refer to the guideline entitled ‘Management of Women with VTE (DVT/PE) during the antenatal and postnatal period'; register number 12007)

The risk of developing pressure ulcers is greater in this patient group and staff must continue to assess and manage potential pressure injury, whilst the patient remains immobile. Referral to the tissue viability nurse should be made if necessary.

As the risk of wound infection is increased, all wounds must be observed and advice given regarding care. Medical opinion on the ward or by general practitioner (GP) should be sought immediately if a wound infection/ breakdown is suspected.
For contraception, the combined oral contraceptive pills increases the risk of venous thromboembolism (VTE) and alternative contraception should be discussed and offered.
Patients with significantly raised BMI will need extra support with breast feeding.
Equipment review

The Labour Ward Manager will be responsible for undertaking an equipment review annually. This will assess the availability of suitable equipment in all care settings regarding a patient with a BMI ≥  kg/m.
Any deficiencies identified through the audit process will be addressed via the Maternity Risk Management Group (MRMG); refer to point 14.4.
Training requirements
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training, which includes skills and drills training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are up- to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Guideline management

14.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Professional midwifery advocates

Professional Midwifery Advocates provide a mechanism of support and guidance to women and midwives. Professional Midwifery Advocates are experienced practising midwives who have undertaken further education in order to supervise midwifery services and to advise and support midwives and women in their care choices.
Infection prevention
Staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
When taking bloods samples or carrying out procedures such as the application of a fetal scalp electrode an aseptic non -touch technique (ANTT) should be followed.

All invasive devices must be inserted and cared for using high impact intervention guidelines (refer to Saving Lives policy guideline, DoH, 2007) to reduce the risk of infection and deliver safe care. This care should be recorded in the Saving Lives High Impact Intervention Monitoring Tool Paperwork (Medical Devices).
Audit and monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.
As a minimum the following specific requirements will be monitored:
Calculation and documentation of body mass index (BMI) in the health records
Calculation and documentation of the BMI in the electronic patient information system
Requirement that all women with a BMI ≥35 kg/m should be advised to deliver in an obstetric led unit
Requirement that all women with a BMI ≥40 kg/m have an antenatal consultation with an obstetric anaesthetist
Requirement that a documented obstetric anaesthetic management plan for labour and delivery should be discussed with all women with a BMI ≥40 kg/m
Requirement that all women with a BMI ≥30 kg/m have a documented antenatal consultation with an appropriately trained professional to discuss possible intrapartum complications
Requirement to assess the availability of suitable equipment in all care settings for women with a high BMI

Requirement that all women with a BMI ≥40 kg/m have an individual documented assessment in the third trimester of pregnancy by an appropriately trained professional to determine manual handling requirements for childbirth and consider tissue viability issues
Process for audit, multidisciplinary review of audit results and subsequent monitoring of action plans

A review of a suitable sample of health records of patients to include the minimum requirements as highlighted in point 15.2 will be audited. A minimum compliance 75% is required for each requirement. Where concerns are identified more frequent audit will be undertaken.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be circulated clinically and local approval obtained from the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group prior to submission to the Controlled Document Team for ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the Guidelines and Audit Nurse's and author's responsibility to inform appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
References

Mothers and Babies: Reducing Risk through Audits and Confidential Enquiries Across the UK (MBRRACE-UK), (2019). Saving lives, improving mothers' care: lessons learned to inform maternity care from the UK and Ireland: confidential enquiries into maternal deaths and morbidity 2015-17. Oxford:MBRRACE-UK. Available at: www.npeu.ox.ac.uk/assets/downloads/mbrrace-uk/reports/MBRRACE- UK%20Maternal%20Report%202019%20-%20WEB%20VERSION.pdf
Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, (2015). Thrombosis and embolism during pregnancy and the puerperium, reducing the risk. (Green-top Guideline No 37a) London:RCOG.
Available at: www.rcog.org.uk/en/guidelines-research-services/guidelines/gtg37a/

Royal Collage of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists (2015). Thrombosis and embolism during pregnancy and the puerperium, acute management. (Greentop- Guideline No 37b). London:RCOG. Available at: www.rcog.org.uk/en/guidelines- research-services/guidlelines/gtg37b/

Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecoloists, (2018). Care of women with obesity in pregnancy. (Green-top Guideline No 72). London:RCOG. Available at https://www.rcog.org.uk/en/guidelines-research-services/guidelines/gtg72/

Association of Anaesthetists and the Obstetric Anaesthetists' Association, (2013). OAA/AAGBI Guidelines for obstetric anaesthetic services. London: AAGBI/OAA. Available at: https://anaesthetists.org/Home/Resources-publications/Guidelines/Obstetric- anaesthetic-service
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence, (2010). Weight management
before, during and after pregnancy.(Public health guideline PH27). London:NICE. Available at: www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ph27
Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, (2015). Advice on nutrition in pregnancy: RCOG statement. Available at: www.rcog.org.uk/en/news/rcog- statement-advice-on-nutrition-in-pregnancy/
Confidential Enquiries into Maternal Deaths in the United Kingdom. (2011). Saving Mothers' Lives: Reviewing Maternal Deaths To Make Motherhood Safer: 2006-
2008. London: Wiley-Blackwell. Available at:  http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com
Centre for Maternal and Child Enquires, Royal College of Obstetricians and
Gynaecologists (2010). Management Of Women With Obesity In Pregnancy.
London: CMACE/RCOG. Available at: www.rcog.org.uk/globalassets/documents/guidelines/cmacercogjointguidelinemanag ementwomenobesitypregnancya.pdf
Centre for Maternal and Child Enquiries (2010). Maternal Obesity In The UK: Findings From A National Project. London: CMACE. Available at: www.oaa-
anaes.ac.uk
National Institute for Health and Clinical Excellence (NICE). (2008). Antenatal Care: Routine Care For The Healthy Pregnant Woman. London: NICE. Available at:
www.nice.org.uk

table_items.text: Booked for Delivery at Consultant-led Unit, Broomfield Hospital
Oral Glucose Tolerance Test at 24-28 weeks
BMI ≥ 30 - with NO other risk factors
BMI ≥ 30 - with additional risk factors and BMI ≥ 35
Date of first appointment: BMI ≥ 40 - Anaesthetic appointment
Gestation weight gain, BMI ≥ 30 (Institute of medicine 2009)
On admission to labour ward with a BMI ≥ 40; utilise room 6 if available

data.text: Appendix C
SUPPLIMENTARY SHEDULE OF ANTENATAL VISITS FOR WOMEN WITH RAISED BMI IN ADDITION TO NORMAL CARE PATHWAY

table_items.text: CARE FOR WOMEN WITH A BMI ≥ 30

+ Commence pro- forma + Discuss diet and exercise + Give Patient information leaflet for Weight Control in pregnancy. + Offer referral to Provide Essex Lifestyle Service via Intranet. Random blood glucose & HbA1c.
As for women with BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2including: Commence 75mg Asprin orally via GP; if there is another risk factor present (refer to page 34 of the Antenatal Care Record for indications)
As for women with BMI ≥ 35 kg/m2 including: Possible referral to Dietetics team.
Possible consultant visit if additional risk factors
Consultant visit Lifestyle assessment. Discuss risks
Possible consultant visit if additional risk factors. Fasting glucose and HbA1C.
Consultant visit Fasting glucose and HbA1C.
Consultant visit Fasting glucose and HbA1C.
Midwife visit for primips. Discuss prep for breast feeding.
Midwife visit for primips. Discuss preparation for breast feeding.
Midwife visit. Discuss preparation for breast feeding.
Additional growth scan followed by consultant
Midwife visit. Final weight Manual handling assessment
Midwife or consultant visit. Final weight Manual handling assessment
Consultant visit Final weight Manual handling assessment
Additional growth scan followed by consultant
